Questions and related hypotheses: H1.1. FACFs decrease linearly with latitude (L-)
Related references: Luyssaert et al. (2007); Gillman et al. (2015); Simova and Storch (2017)

Questions and related hypotheses: H2.1. FACFs increase linearly with MAT (L+)
H2.2. FACFs increase with precipitation but saturate or decrease at very high levels (CD+)
H2.3. There is a postive interaction between temperature and precipitation (I+)
H3.1. FACFs increase with PET, but saturate or decrease at high levels (CD+)
H3.2. FACFs increase with vapour pressure deficit, but saturate or decrease at high levels (CD+)
H3.3. FACFs increase linearly with solar radiation (L+)
H4.1. FACFs decrease linearly with temperature seasonality (L-)
H4.2. FACFs decrease linearly with precipitation seasonality (L-)
H4.3. FACFs increase linearly with growing season length (L+)
Related references: Malhi (2012); Michaletz et al. (2014); Chu et al. (2016)

Questions and related hypotheses: H4.4. Growing season length is a better predictor of FACFs than MAT
Related references: Michaletz et al. (2014); Chu et al. (2016)

Questions and related hypotheses: H5.1. Growing season FACFs increase with temperature (L+)
H5.2. Growing season FACFs increase with PET (L+)
H5.3. Growing season FACFs increase with precipitation (L+)
H5.4. Growing season FACFs increase with solar radiation (L+)
